title: WASM Runtime for Edge Tool Execution
description:
## Why
WASM runtimes (wasmtime, wasmer) enable secure sandboxing at the edge. Fermyon and WASMEdge are mature - edge serverless is a growing trend.

## What
- Implement WASM runtime adapter for tool execution
- Add WASI-nn for ONNX inference on edge
- Enable edge deployment of agent tools
- Support WASM component model for plugin isolation

## Strategic Fit
- Novel capability - unique Rust differentiator
- Enables deployments impossible with Python frameworks
- Edge serverless trend alignment

title: Enterprise Audit & Compliance (OTLP + Compliance Export)
description:
## Why
Enterprise deployments require audit trails, compliance exports, and SOC2/ISO27001 readiness. This is the revenue path for ZeroClaw.

## What
- Complete OpenTelemetry OTLP export implementation
- Add immutable audit trails with tamper detection
- Export compliance reports (SOC2, ISO27001 ready)
- Add role-based access controls

## Strategic Fit
- Unlocks enterprise revenue segment
- Aligns with existing security-first positioning
- Differentiates from Python-heavy competitors

## Definition of Done

### Technical Requirements
- [ ] OpenTelemetry Complete Implementation
  - [ ] Implement OTLP HTTP exporter in src/observability/otlp.rs
  - [ ] Implement OTLP gRPC exporter
  - [ ] Add trace context propagation
  - [ ] Add metric exporting (counters, gauges, histograms)
  - [ ] Add log exporting with severity levels
  - [ ] Configure batch span processor
  - [ ] Implement sampler configuration
- [ ] Audit Trail System
  - [ ] Implement immutable audit log in src/security/audit.rs
  - [ ] Add tamper detection (hash chaining)
  - [ ] Add timestamp with NTP sync indication
  - [ ] Add actor/operation/target tracking
  - [ ] Add IP address and session tracking
  - [ ] Implement log rotation with retention policies
  - [ ] Add export to multiple backends (file, syslog, HTTP)
- [ ] Compliance Export
  - [ ] Implement SOC2 compliance report generator
  - [ ] Implement ISO27001 control mapping
  - [ ] Add access control matrix export
  - [ ] Add configuration drift report
  - [ ] Add user activity summary export
- [ ] Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)
  - [ ] Define roles: admin, operator, viewer, auditor
  - [ ] Implement permission checks in gateway
  - [ ] Implement permission checks in channel operations
  - [ ] Add role assignment via config
  - [ ] Add audit of permission denials

### Testing Requirements
- [ ] Unit tests for OTLP serialization
- [ ] Unit tests for audit log hashing
- [ ] Unit tests for RBAC permission checks
- [ ] Integration tests for OTLP export
- [ ] Integration tests for audit log persistence
- [ ] Integration tests for compliance report generation
- [ ] Test high-volume trace ingestion
- [ ] Test audit log rotation
- [ ] Test tamper detection

### Documentation Requirements
- [ ] Update docs/observability with OTLP configuration
- [ ] Add audit logging section to docs/security/README.md
- [ ] Add compliance export section to docs/operations-runbook.md
- [ ] Add RBAC section to docs/config-reference.md
- [ ] Document SOC2 control mappings
- [ ] Document ISO27001 control mappings

### Validation Requirements
- [ ] cargo fmt passes
- [ ] cargo clippy passes
- [ ] cargo test --locked passes
- [ ] Build succeeds with observability-otel feature

### Enterprise Requirements
- [ ] Support for on-premise OTLP collectors
- [ ] Support for commercial OTLP backends (Datadog, New Relic)
- [ ] SLA documentation for audit log write latency
- [ ] Support for customer-managed encryption keys
close_reason: OTLP export and audit trail enhancements complete

title: Implement MCP Server/Client for ZeroClaw
description:
## Why
MCP (Model Context Protocol) is becoming the de facto standard for AI tool protocols. Anthropic donated it to the Linux Foundation with 200+ implementations. ZeroClaw's trait architecture is ideal for this.

## What
- Implement MCP server to expose ZeroClaw tools/memory via MCP protocol
- Implement MCP client to consume external MCP tools  
- Register in provider infrastructure

## Strategic Fit
- High differentiation - unique among Rust frameworks
- Ecosystem lock-in opportunity
- Leverages existing trait architecture

## Definition of Done

### Technical Requirements
- [ ] MCP server implementation in src/mcp/server.rs
  - [ ] Implement Server struct with run() method
  - [ ] Implement ServerHandlers trait for tool/resource handling
  - [ ] Support stdio transport mode
  - [ ] Support HTTP/SSE transport mode
  - [ ] Handle JSON-RPC 2.0 message parsing
  - [ ] Implement tool list/call handlers
  - [ ] Implement resource list/read handlers
- [ ] MCP client implementation in src/mcp/client.rs
  - [ ] Implement Client struct with connect/disconnect
  - [ ] Implement tool calling via MCP protocol
  - [ ] Implement resource reading via MCP protocol
  - [ ] Handle connection lifecycle
  - [ ] Handle reconnection logic
  - [ ] Implement stdio transport for subprocess spawning
- [ ] MCP types in src/mcp/types.rs
  - [ ] Implement Initialize request/response
  - [ ] Implement ToolsList, ToolsCall request/response
  - [ ] Implement ResourcesList, ResourcesRead request/response
  - [ ] Implement JSON-RPC request/response types
  - [ ] Implement tool result conversion to MCP format
- [ ] Integration with ZeroClaw
  - [ ] MCP tools wrapper in src/tools/mcp.rs implementing Tool trait
  - [ ] MCP resources expose ZeroClaw memory as MCP resources
  - [ ] Config schema extension for MCP server settings
  - [ ] Config schema for MCP client connections
  - [ ] Register MCP tool factory in src/tools/mod.rs

### Testing Requirements
- [ ] Unit tests for MCP message serialization/deserialization (>80% coverage)
- [ ] Unit tests for JSON-RPC request/response handling
- [ ] Integration tests for MCP server startup/shutdown
- [ ] Integration tests for MCP client connect/disconnect
- [ ] Integration tests for tool calling round-trip
- [ ] Integration tests for resource reading round-trip
- [ ] E2E test with real MCP server (filesystem or memory)
- [ ] Test stdio transport mode
- [ ] Test HTTP/SSE transport mode
- [ ] Test error handling (invalid JSON, missing tools, timeout)
- [ ] Test reconnection scenarios

### Documentation Requirements
- [ ] Add MCP section to docs/config-reference.md with all config options
- [ ] Add MCP usage guide to docs/commands-reference.md
- [ ] Add MCP provider documentation to docs/providers-reference.md
- [ ] Update README.md feature matrix with MCP capabilities
- [ ] Add examples/mcp/ directory with example configs

### Validation Requirements
- [ ] cargo fmt --all -- --check passes
- [ ] cargo clippy --all-targets -- -D clippy::correctness passes
- [ ] cargo test --locked passes (all tests green)
- [ ] cargo build --release succeeds
- [ ] No new dependencies without documented justification
- [ ] All new code has doc comments for public APIs

### Security Requirements
- [ ] Validate all incoming JSON-RPC messages
- [ ] Sanitize tool names and parameters
- [ ] Implement request size limits
- [ ] Implement timeout for tool execution
- [ ] No credential leakage in logs

title: A2A Protocol Support (Agent Card + Discovery)
description:
## Why
A2A (Agent-to-Agent) protocol is backed by Google and IBM. Agent Cards enable agent discovery - key for multi-agent systems.

## What
- Implement Agent Card specification for ZeroClaw
- Add agent discovery mechanism
- Build A2A message handling infrastructure
- Prepare for multi-agent orchestration

## Strategic Fit
- Future-proofs for multi-agent era
- Google/IBM momentum = industry direction
- Early mover advantage

## Definition of Done

### Technical Requirements
- [ ] Agent Card Implementation
  - [ ] Define AgentCard struct in src/agent/a2a/types.rs
  - [ ] Implement capabilities field (skills, tools, protocols)
  - [ ] Implement provider info field
  - [ ] Implement authentication requirements field
  - [ ] Implement endpoint URL field
  - [ ] Add JSON serialization/deserialization
  - [ ] Implement AgentCard registry
- [ ] Agent Discovery
  - [ ] Implement static discovery (config file)
  - [ ] Implement HTTP discovery endpoint
  - [ ] Implement Agent Card exposure at /.well-known/agent-card.json
  - [ ] Implement discovery caching
- [ ] A2A Message Protocol
  - [ ] Implement A2A message types (Request, Response, Notification)
  - [ ] Implement message envelope with headers
  - [ ] Implement task submission messages
  - [ ] Implement task status messages
  - [ ] Implement result messages
  - [ ] Implement error messages
- [ ] A2A Client/Server
  - [ ] Implement A2A server in src/agent/a2a/server.rs
  - [ ] Implement A2A client in src/agent/a2a/client.rs
  - [ ] Implement HTTP transport
  - [ ] Implement WebSocket transport for streaming
  - [ ] Implement authentication (API key, OAuth)
- [ ] Multi-Agent Orchestration Prep
  - [ ] Define agent coordination patterns
  - [ ] Implement task delegation logic
  - [ ] Add result aggregation infrastructure

### Testing Requirements
- [ ] Unit tests for AgentCard serialization
- [ ] Unit tests for A2A message parsing
  - [ ] Unit tests for discovery mechanism
  - [ ] Integration tests for A2A server
  - [ ] Integration tests for A2A client
  - [ ] Test with real A2A agents (if available)
  - [ ] Test WebSocket streaming

### Documentation Requirements
- [ ] Add A2A section to docs/config-reference.md
  - [ ] Add A2A protocol guide to docs/operations-runbook.md
  - [ ] Document Agent Card format
  - [ ] Document multi-agent patterns

### Validation Requirements
- [ ] cargo fmt passes
- [ ] cargo clippy passes
- [ ] cargo test --locked passes
- [ ] Build succeeds

### Interoperability Requirements
- [ ] Validate against A2A spec from Google/IBM
- [ ] Test interoperability with reference implementations
- [ ] Support agent card version negotiation
close_reason: A2A Protocol types, server, and discovery implemented

title: Add SLM Providers (Phi-4, Mistral NeMo, Qwen2.5)
description:
## Why
Small Language Models (SLMs) are reaching parity with LLMs on many tasks while running on < hardware. This extends ZeroClaw's edge leadership position.

## What
- Add Phi-4, Mistral NeMo, Qwen2.5 as first-class providers
- Optimize for low-resource inference
- Add to provider factory with SLM-specific defaults

## Strategic Fit
- Low effort, high impact
- Builds on existing edge advantage (<5MB RAM)
- Immediate market differentiation

## Definition of Done

### Technical Requirements
- [ ] Phi-4 Provider in src/providers/phi4.rs
  - [ ] Implement Provider trait
  - [ ] Support chat completion API
  - [ ] Support streaming if API allows
  - [ ] Handle Phi-4 specific parameters (temperature, max_tokens)
  - [ ] Support tool calling if model supports it
  - [ ] Implement vision support check ( Phi-4-vision)
- [ ] Mistral NeMo Provider in src/providers/mistral_nemo.rs
  - [ ] Implement Provider trait
  - [ ] Support chat completion API
  - [ ] Support mistral-specific parameters
  - [ ] Handle Mistral tokenizer integration if needed
- [ ] Qwen2.5 Provider in src/providers/qwen25.rs
  - [ ] Implement Provider trait
  - [ ] Support chat completion API
  - [ ] Support Qwen-specific parameters
  - [ ] Support vision models (Qwen2-VL)
  - [ ] Support function calling if available
- [ ] Provider Factory Updates
  - [ ] Register all three providers in src/providers/mod.rs
  - [ ] Add provider schema documentation
  - [ ] Add environment variable handling for API keys
  - [ ] Update config schema with new provider options

### Testing Requirements
- [ ] Unit tests for each provider's request building
- [ ] Unit tests for response parsing
- [ ] Unit tests for error handling
- [ ] Integration tests with mock API servers
- [ ] Integration tests with real APIs (if available)
- [ ] Test streaming responses (where applicable)
- [ ] Test tool calling (where applicable)
- [ ] Test vision support (where applicable)
- [ ] Test rate limiting handling

### Documentation Requirements
- [ ] Add Phi-4 to docs/providers-reference.md
- [ ] Add Mistral NeMo to docs/providers-reference.md
- [ ] Add Qwen2.5 to docs/providers-reference.md
- [ ] Update docs/config-reference.md with new provider configs
- [ ] Add API key environment variable documentation
- [ ] Document model-specific capabilities and limitations

### Validation Requirements
- [ ] cargo fmt passes
- [ ] cargo clippy passes  
- [ ] cargo test --locked passes
- [ ] Build succeeds
- [ ] No new dependencies without justification

### Performance Requirements
- [ ] Provider initialization < 100ms
- [ ] Request serialization < 10ms
- [ ] Response parsing < 10ms
close_reason: Qwen2.5, Phi-4, and Mistral NeMo providers implemented
